children.name: vocabulary
children.definition: /vocabinformal
examples: 1[C or U] A2 all the words that someone knows or uses :
Teachers were impressed by his vocabulary.
2[C] C1 all the words in a particular language :
English has the largest vocabulary of any language.
3[C or U] C1 the words that are typically used when talking about a particular subject :
Most technical jobs use a specialized vocabulary.
vocabulary of
the vocabulary of politics

children.name: large/wide/extensive
examples: She has a very wide vocabulary.

children.name: limited/small
examples: He had just started learning English and his vocabulary was fairly limited.

children.name: basic/essential vocabulary
examples: The book teaches you the basic vocabulary that you need to know when you're on holiday.

children.name: technical/specialized vocabulary
examples: The instructions were full of technical vocabulary.

children.name: somebody's active vocabulary
children.definition: the words they can use
examples: Children of this age have an active vocabulary of about 1,000 words.

children.name: somebody's passive vocabulary
children.definition: the words they can understand but do not use
examples: Your passive vocabulary is much larger than your active vocabulary.

children.name: have a vocabulary
examples: By eighteen months of age, the girl had a vocabulary of around 300 words.

children.name: expand/improve your vocabulary
children.definition: alsoenrich your vocabularyformal
examples: Reading helps to expand your vocabulary.

children.name: learn vocabulary
examples: What's the best way of learning new vocabulary?

children.name: a vocabulary test/exercise
examples: The teacher gave us a vocabulary test.

children.name: a vocabulary itemformal
children.definition: a word, especially in a coursebook or a language class
examples: The difficult vocabulary items are explained at the bottom of the page.

children.name: terminology
children.definition: all the technical words or expressions that are used in connection with a particular subject: thuật ngữ
examples: One of the hardest things when studying linguistics is learning all the right terminology.
terminological[adj]

children.name: legal/medical/scientific etc terminology
examples: In legal terminology, a widow is the ‘relict’ of her late husband.
Kelly wants to be a nurse, and is taking a medical terminology class at night.

children.name: word
children.definition: a single group of letters that are used together with a particular meaning :
examples: Write an essay of about five hundred words.
What does that word mean?

children.name: a new word
examples: Computer technology has brought many new words into our language.

children.name: the right/exact word
children.definition: the word that has the meaning you want
examples: He struggled to find the right word.

children.name: a
examples: German/Italian etc wordProsciutto is the Italian word for ham.

children.name: a long word
examples: She didn’t understand all the long words.

children.name: big words
children.definition: words that sound very important or serious
examples: It scares me, when you use big words like that.

children.name: a five-letter/nine-letter etc word
examples: Can you think of a six-letter word meaning ‘difficult’?

children.name: a rude word
examples: Someone had written a rude word on the back of his chair.

children.name: a swear word
examples: He learned a few swear words on the playground.

children.name: a dirty word
children.definition: a rude word
examples: You couldn’t say dirty words on television.

children.name: a four-letter word
children.definition: a very rude word
examples: The programme was full of four letter words.

children.name: a taboo word
children.definition: one that people are not allowed to use
examples: This has now become a taboo word.

children.name: say/speak a word
examples: She said the words ‘my husband’ in a firm voice.

children.name: use a word
examples: Be very careful how you use the word ‘natural’.

children.name: pronounce a word
examples: How do you pronounce this word?

children.name: spell a word
examples: I always find that word hard to spell.

children.name: have a word
examples: It is not true that Eskimos have more than forty words for snow.

children.name: find the word
children.definition: succeed in thinking of the right word to use
examples: She couldn’t find the words to explain how she felt.

children.name: search for words
children.definition: try to think of words to use
examples: She hesitated, searching for words.

children.name: look up a word
children.definition: try to find it in a book
examples: I looked the word up in my dictionary.

children.name: word for sthword that means something
examples: 'Vater' is the Germanword for'father'.

children.name: a short worda short word beginning with ‘d’ and ending with ‘g’
catchword
children.definition: a word or phrase that people use in a particular situation, because it describes what is important in that situation: khẩu lệnh
examples: Variety will be the catchword at the new venue, with acts ranging from stand-up comedy to poetry readings.
After World War II, the catchword for a newly health-conscious society was ‘protein’.

children.name: antonym
children.definition: specialized a word which means the opposite of another word :từ trái nghĩa
examples: Two antonyms of 'light' are 'dark' and 'heavy'.

children.name: term
children.definition: a word or expression with a particular meaning, especially one that is used for a specific subject or type of language : thuật ngữ

children.name: a legal/medical term
examples: The site provides a glossary of legal terms.

children.name: a technical term‘
examples: Gender’ is a technical term in grammar.

children.name: a slang term‘
examples: The Old Bill’ is a slang term for the police.

children.name: a derogatory/pejorative term
children.definition: one that is insulting or disapproving
examples: ‘Pinko’ is a derogatory term for someone with socialist ideas.

children.name: coin a term
children.definition: invent it
examples: Funk coined the term ‘vitamin’ in 1912.

children.name: a term of abuse
children.definition: a word that is offensive or deliberately rude
examples: ‘Geek’ is used as a term of abuse.

children.name: a term of endearment
children.definition: a word that expresses your love for someone
examples: terms of endearment like ‘love’, ‘dear’, and ‘honey’

children.name: in strong terms
examples: The Pope condemned both Nazism and Communism in strong terms.

children.name: in glowing terms
children.definition: praising someone or something highly
examples: Friends and relatives speak of him in glowing terms.

children.name: in layman’s terms
children.definition: using ordinary words, not technical words
examples: Can you explain to me in layman’s terms how my computer works?

children.name: term for
examples: ‘Multimedia’ is the term for any technique combining sounds and images.

children.name: in no uncertain terms(= in very clear and angry language )
examples: Journalists were told in no uncertain terms that they were not welcome.

children.name: use a terma term used by psychiatrists
synonym
children.definition: technicala word with the same meaning as another word in the same language:từ đồng nghĩa
examples: The words 'small' and 'little' are synonyms.
synonymous[adj] C2 having the same meaning
The words 'annoyed' and 'irritated' are more or less synonymous.

children.name: synonym for/of
examples: ‘Shut’ is a synonym of ‘closed’.

children.name: buzzword
children.definition: a word or phrase from one special area of knowledge that people suddenly start using a lot, especially because they think it means sth important: từ thông dụng, thịnh hành
examples: The big Internet buzzword at the moment is ‘push technology’.
Customer-friendliness was the buzzword in British business circles.
‘Going snap’ on a decision was the latest buzzword in our office.

children.name: homonym
children.definition: a word that sounds the same or is spelled the same as another word but has a different meaning : từ đồng âm
examples: 'No' and 'know' are homonyms.
'Bow' (= bend at the waist) and 'bow' (= weapon) are also homonyms.

children.name: coinage
children.definition: (the inventing of) a new word or phrase in a language :từ mới; cụm từ mới
examples: The expression 'boy band' is a nineties coinage.

children.name: homograph
children.definition: specialized a word which is spelled the same as another word and might be pronounced the same or differently, but which has a different meaning:từ cùng chữ
examples: 'Bow' meaning the front of a ship, 'bow' meaning a loop made in a string or ribbon and 'bow' meaning a device used to shoot arrows are all homographs.

children.name: loanword
children.definition: a word taken from one language and used in another :từ ngoại lai; từ vay mượn

children.name: abbreviation
children.definition: a short form of a word or expression :viết tắt

children.name: abbreviation of/for
examples: ‘Dr’ is the written abbreviation of ‘Doctor’.
'ITV' is the abbreviationfor'Independent Television'.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually saybe short forinstead ofbe the abbreviation of/for:
W.H.O.is short for‘World Health Organization’.
